intro: Dacryodes dungii, commonly known as the Dung Island ironwood, is a tropical evergreen tree native to the Philippines. It belongs to the family Burseraceae and is characterized by its dense, aromatic wood and thick, waxy leaves. The plant typically grows in lowland to montane forests and is well adapted to humid, warm climates. Its flowers are small and clustered, and it produces drupes that are an important food source for various wildlife. Due to its ecological significance and limited distribution, it is considered a vulnerable species.
